title: How to get sent free books to review - Quora

response.answer_text: It is actually quite easy, especially if you want to review certain titles: You can either contact the writers or the publishers directly. Especially publishers offer a way for reviewers to contact them. Look for items like “For Bloggers/For media” in the navigation menu of the publisher’s website. There are also Facebook groups dedicated to connecting authors and reviewers. But keep in mind: Writers as well as publishers will expect you having a platform. You put your reviews on Amazon or any other book retail site? Not good enough. Goodreads or other online book communities? Better, though it depends on how many followers you have there. Same goes for Facebook. Got a blog? Now we’re talking. How many unique visitors/visits to you have per month and per article? Under triple digits? Forget it. You write for newspapers, magazines, even fanzines and you get your articles/reviews published regularly? Here is your copy! Those are the reviews that usually have the largest reach for us. We might also look at the quality of your reviews: One paragraph reviews, riddled with typos? Generic text like “This is a nice book and the cover is blue”? Simply copying the blurb or write one sentence? These kinds of reviews are of no use to us. So, if you are serious about this, start writing reviews about books you already know/have. Take writing those reviews seriously. Build your platform. And it is always easier to get a copy of a certain book for review (if you can plead your case accordingly) than just asking “Send me books”.

Some authors keep lists of reviewers, who they send pre-release copies to, in the hope of reviews. So approaching you fav author could get you added to their list, although you’re more likely to get an Indie add you than a Trad. Alternately, there are sites where you can sign up. Google. Or you can find authors on FB groups and author forums.
The publisher would have to believe that your views are valuable to them and that does not mean that you promise to be a sycophant.
